webTitle: Letters: There is hope for the Co-op Bank's future

fields.body:
As fresh investigations are launched into Barclays' dubious activities, the sense of a potential new direction for the bank generated by Antony Jenkins' appointment has all but evaporated (Report, 31 October). Since Jenkins announced in February that Barclays was pulling out of food speculation, the World Development Movement has asked the bank four times to clarify what proportion of its agricultural commodities business has actually been closed down. When it finally came, the answer was, in effect, "we're not telling you". So while Barclays has bowed to public outrage by ending its own speculation on food, it continues to enable clients, such as institutional investors, to profit from the practice. Food speculation fuels food price spikes and contributes to the global hunger crisis. Through its continued involvement, Barclays puts its profits above the basic human need for food.
Nick Dearden
Director, World Development Movement

• The Co-operative Bank picked up customers while other banks were being rescued by taxpayers' money. It was also named the world's most environmentally sustainable bank by the FT. Now it has been laid low, with weaknesses that might appear endemic to the banking sector, it's easy to assume that the ethics will ebb away (Letters, 5 November). This doesn't have to be the outcome and I suggest we give it time to judge the truth of this.

We of course welcome the plans to preserve co-operative values and ethics within the bank's constitution, for which the Co-operative Group deserves much credit for during negotiations. If the current proposals work out, there remains a degree of co-operative influence over the bank. Like the new wave of ethical "B corporations" in the US, it plans to have ethics entrenched in its articles. The bank was a pioneer of ethical reporting, independently audited and increasingly sophisticated. If this continues, there will be a measure of public accountability. The end of mutual ownership is not necessarily the end of its ethics.
Ed Mayo
Secretary general, Co-operatives UK

webTitle: Goldman Sachs co-operates with foreign exchange trading inquiry

fields.standfirst: Bank joins JP Morgan, RBS, Citigroup and others involved in inquiry into potential rigging of currency benchmarks
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs has become the latest bank to admit it is co-operating with regulators over an inquiry into potential manipulation of the foreign exchange markets, where more than £3tn of currencies change hands each day.

In a quarterly regulatory filing with US Securities and Exchange Commission, the biggest investment bank in America added currencies and commodities to the list of items with which it is in discussions with regulators.

The bank also set aside a further $500m (£311m) to cover potential litigation in reviews by regulatory bodies.

Two other US banks – JP Morgan and Citigroup – have said they are involved in the global investigation into potential rigging of currency benchmarks. Barclays, RBS, UBS, Deutsche Bank are among the European banks also co-operating with regulators.

The announcement by Goldman came as the London Metal Exchange took steps to tackle concern about queues at its warehouses, used to store metals traded on its exchange. Reuters reported that the measures were to counter criticism that firms such as Goldman Sachs have been artificially inflating waiting times and queues to boost rents for warehouse owners and cause metal prices to rise.

webTitle: RBS agrees £95m settlement over sub-prime misselling claims

fields.standfirst: Agreement with US Securities and Exchange Commission comes just after S&P downgraded bailed-out bank's debt
fields.body:
The legacy of the banking crisis continued to haunt the new management of Royal Bank of Scotland after the bailed out bank paid $153m (£95m) to settle claims it missold sub-prime mortgages.

The penalty, agreed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, comes as Ross McEwan, the bank's new chief executive, attempts to focus the bank on its customers and create a new division holding £38bn of loans that may not be repaid.

The settlement was announced just hours after a leading ratings agency downgraded RBS's debt. Standard & Poors made a one-notch downgrade to the long-term and short-term counter party rating, blaming McEwan's restructuring of the bank, which will force RBS to report a loss for 2013. S&P also expressed concern about the bank's "potentially substantial exposure to litigation and conduct risk".

The SEC had alleged that the bank misled investors about the quality of the mortgages in a $2.2bn package of loans sold in 2007. The regulator described the package as "shoddy".

RBS has neither admitted nor denied the allegations in its settlement with the regulator. It had been in discussions with the SEC for many months and other banks have already announced settlements. George Canellos, a director of the SEC enforcement division, said the bank had "cut corners" and that 30% of the mortgages packaged up should have been excluded from the bond offering – from which it earned $4.4m in fees.

S&P is also keeping the bank's rating on a negative outlook – indicating another downgrade is possible – because of its negative view on the overall UK banking industry.

The changes announced last Friday by RBS mean it will take a £4.5bn hit to put £38bn of troublesome loans into what will be known as the capital resolution division. The new division is being set up after a review by Rothschild, commissioned by the chancellor George Osborne, had considered – and ruled out – creating a much larger, separate bad bank.

The bank, 81% owned by the taxpayer, told the stock market it was "disappointed" by S&P's move, particularly as other ratings agencies had decided against a downgrade. S&P said: "The lowering of the ratings reflects our view of the changes that RBS has announced, which include the creation of an internal 'bad bank' and the accelerated disposals of higher-risk assets. In our view, these changes create additional near-term execution risks and further delay the group's return to sustainable organic capital build."

Ratings can influence the price that the bank pays to borrow money or have an impact on the types of institutions that can place money with the bank. But RBS said: "We are not expecting this downgrade to have a material adverse impact on the liquidity of the group." The shares were down 2% at 321p.

webTitle: Halfords profits beat expectations amid cycling boom

fields.standfirst: Soaring sales of upmarket bicycles and warm weather helped pretax profits rise 5.2% to £44.6m in the six months to September
fields.body:
Soaring sales of upmarket bicycles, boosted by a fine summer and a string of successes by British cyclists in international events, have helped Halfords' profits surge beyond City expectations, sending its shares to a three-year high.

The retailer and car service company, which is in the middle of a turnaround plan intended to raise sales to £1bn by 2016, revealed pretax profits had risen 5.2% to £44.6m in the six months to September – a figure that was 20% better than analysts expected.

Underlying sales rose 6.2% as the company sold 26% more upmarket bicycles and 17% more kids' bikes than in the same period last year, offsetting a 2.1% decline in underlying sales at Halfords' car service centres. Online sales were particularly strong, up nearly 17%, helping deliver total sales for the group of £490.6m in the half.

Shares rose 14.4% to 478p, recovering to well above the point they dived from in May when chief executive Matt Davies said he was cutting dividend payments to invest in training staff and improving stores under his turnaround plan.

Davies, who joined the company in October last year, said: "These are good results but there is still plenty to do. We are happy with the progress so far but we are just in the early stages of growing the business so its important that non of us get carried away."

The former Pets at Home boss said that sales had been boosted by good weather over the summer and a string of successes by British cyclists in international events including the Tour de France.

He warned that sales had "surpassed expectation" in the first half of the year but things could get tougher over Christmas. "Last Chistmas we saw people buying electronic toys and that didn't help our kids bike business," he said.

webTitle: ECB cuts rates: Mario Draghi was right to insist on immediate action

fields.bodyText: All credit to Mario Draghi. The European Central Bank caught the financial markets totally unawares when it cut its key interest rate to 0.25% and there was an instant response. The euro - perilously overvalued on the foreign exchanges - fell like a stone. Draghi clearly had to overcome resistance from the ECB council, with some members seeking to delay any easing of policy to a later date. This would have been a mistake. The latest figures show the euro area flirting dangerously with deflation, with prices rising at an annual rate of just 0.7%. Try as he might to dispel the idea, the euro area today is starting to look worryingly like Japan in the early 1990s. Credit flows have dried up, a double dip recession has left oodles of spare capacity, and there is plenty of deflationary pressure coming down the pipeline, from the falling cost of food to lower prices for manufactured goods. Deflation is already a reality for the troubled countries on the fringes of monetary union, with the real and present danger of the core following before too long. So Draghi was quite right to face down the Bundesbank and insist on immediate action. The fall in the value of the euro will - if sustained - help avert the threat of deflation by increasing the cost of imports. Draghi, therefore, missed a trick when he said the value of the single currency had not been discussed at the ECB's council meeting. This was the opportunity to talk down the euro, getting the maximum out of the cut in borrowing costs. The ECB president also invited derision by saying that the eurozone (unemployment 12.2%, trend rate of growth 1% at best, a broken banking system) had the best economic fundamentals in the world. In truth, deflation threatens to trigger a new phase of the eurozone crisis, because falling prices plus weak growth equals unsustainable debt. The ECB's action is a recognition that it has fallen way behind the curve in dealing with this threat. Further steps will be needed.

5.56pm GMT

Draghi faces the press: analyst reaction

Analysts have been digesting the ECB's surprise interest rate cut, and Mario Draghi's press conference performance (highlights start here....with a summary here)

Here's a selection.

Jessica Hinds of Capital Economics:

Thursday’s rate cut reinforces the divergent stances of monetary policy in the euro-zone and the US. The ECB has just eased policy even further, while the Fed, for all its procrastinating, is still more than likely to scale back its asset purchases before too long. Furthermore, President Draghi added that rates could go even lower and that the ECB was “technically ready” to cut its deposit rate into negative territory.

Meanwhile, we do not expect the strength of peripheral euro-zone government bonds to last just because the ECB has become more accommodative. A small cut to the refi rate will not transform the economic outlook and will not address the deep-seated problems of the peripheral countries such as their high debt burdens.

Indeed, credit spreads on euro-zone peripheral government bonds have fallen all the way back to the sort of levels seen on comparably-rated assets outside the euro-zone. There would therefore appear to be a significant risk of a renewed rise in them over time if and when investors’ concerns about these problems reappear. 

Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities

1) One has to always doff one's hat to Draghi for his ability to "blag a blagger", in rather
stark (sic) contrast to his predecessors, and the conservative Bundesbank type grouping
on the council.

2) The timing for a rate cut is/was always key, and so the decision to "go now" rather
than roll out the red carpet for December made good sense.... but that unfortunately
is where the compliments stop.

3) So to the rationale: the ECB is now expecting a "sustained period of low inflation",
but sees "no risk of deflation" - really? a) Does the ECB has any control over such
a fine dividing line, given that Eurozone CPI is 0.7% y/y? b) One might even ask whether
the ECB is wondering into the BoE's bad forecasting territory? and c) What happened to that
recent suggestion that a very low level of inflation was in fact good for (hard pressed)
Eurozone (above all Club Med) consumers?

4) While he could say nothing else other than that he "believes rate cut is effective"
to then follow it up with "some would say reduction in excess liquidity is due to less
fragmentation" and, that the rate cut "reduces fragmentation in the periphery"
is pushing on a gossamer thin bit of string, the more so when he continued later
with this particular bit of bravado: "fundamentals in the Eurozone are probably
strongest in the world", while saying that the recovery is "proceeding, but is weak
and fragile". Which epithet of these would be best to deploy: a) paradox,
b) oxymoron or c) bipolar?

5) What will this do for growth in the Eurozone economy, employment, indeed bank
lending - not a lot. The fact is that by cutting the income of savers, and in fact discouraging
bank lending by keeping long-term rates at very depressed levels, as well as tying to
persuade businesses and consumers that they actually do not need act now to "lock in"
super low rates, the ECB, Fed and BoE may in fact be depressing the economy, while
exponentially fuelling asset bubbles and widening economic and social gaps.

Mike Ingram of BGC Partners:

Cut and Run at the ECB

What a shocker. The market had assumed, at most, a one in ten chance of the European Central Bank (ECB) cutting rates today and yet they did just that. The ECB refinancing rate was halved to 0.25%. For today at least, European stock and bonds were euphoric and the overly strong Euro has taken a beating. Mission accomplished Mr Draghi.

In actuality, a rate cut has only been a question of ‘when’ rather than ‘if’ for some time now. Euro zone inflation is collapsing while output gaps are large and with feeble growth, set to be persistent. Moreover credit conditions are still tightening, albeit at a slower pace and little progress has been made in bringing down lending rates in Europe’s beleaguered periphery. To top it all, the Euro has been strong – defying the consensus call of a strong dollar. Taken together, I wasn’t kidding when I recently suggested that large swathes of the Euro zone are becoming eerily reminiscent of 1990’s Japan.

And yet most of us have been wrong-footed today. (I included, I thought the Bank would wait for more data before cutting in December). In defence I can only say that even as the economic case for a rate cut became compelling, Team Draghi seem infuriatingly relaxed about the need to ease policy further. Now they have belatedly leapt into action.

So for many reasons, I approached the recently concluded ECB press conference with more than a little curiosity. And while it was another polished performance from Super Mario, I wasn’t greatly comforted by what I heard either. I am now left feeling that while the ECB may no longer be horribly behind the curve, there is little chance they are ahead of it and it is only a matter of time before they are playing catch up again.

It could have been worse of course; a late cut is better than none at all. One on the big positives was that, despite cutting rates to an all-time low, we learned that the ECB ‘continues to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time’. It could easily have signalled that rates at 0.25% were an effective floor, but it didn’t. Moreover, it emerged in the Q&A that such forward guidance was unanimous. The ECB feels it still has a few rate cards left to play.

But this seemingly definitive statement of central bank activism sits uneasily with much else that the ECB had to say this afternoon. For instance, the Euro zone inflation outlook was once again described as ‘broadly balanced’. It clearly hasn’t been in the past and given significant deflationary headwinds, I suspect this remains a mistaken prognosis.

Of more practical concern to most of us is that the ECB’s take on the nascent Euro zone economic recovery also seems threadbare. Having shifted the supposed growth drivers from exports and investment early in the year, to consumption and investment in the summer (as emerging markets swooned and PMIs picked up), it is now apparently all down to consumption. Presumably this belatedly recognises that businesses in the Euro zone remain loathe to invest. Hardly a surprise given ample spare capacity and in many cases continued credit rationing. They are more likely to bolster profits by squeezing employees. If so, sayonara consumption too!

Perhaps the most disturbing part of the ECB’s performance today however, was a seemingly off the cuff remark that Mario Draghi made on the long-term outlook for the Euro zone economy. The Euro zone, he said, ‘had some of the best fundamentals in the world’. (I actually laughed out loud at that point). Mario then proceeded to reel off this secret recipe for economic success: low budget deficits and current account surpluses.

I’m sure Angela Merkel must have been overjoyed, but it strikes me that if the main thrust of economic policy is that the rest of Europe deflates against an already competitive Germany, then the outlook for Europe is grim indeed. At that point the ECB’s hand may be looking quite poor – if the market doesn’t call their bluff first.

Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research

So after spending a good part of the last 18 months stating that Europe would be experiencing uplift in economic fortunes right about now Mr Draghi has had to cut rates today. I found it an unconvincing and contradictory performance in the press conference and found it especially interesting that Mr Draghi basically ignored two questions on QE.

The big question is what can the ECB do next if the worrying recent trends with regard to loan demand and inflation do not reverse. Mr Draghi stated that he had a whole range of instruments left to deal with any deteriorating situation, but the ones he mentioned were very much interest rate options. Cheap money has not yet produced any uptick in loan demand in Europe and it is difficult to see why this should change whether he alters the benchmark rate, the deposit rate or whatever. Banks continue to be in deleveraging mode and companies are not confident enough of the immediate economic outlook to invest.

Thus if the ECB rate cuts do not stimulate loan growth or reverse falling prices then what do they do next? I think the first port of call would be to try and encourage banks to lend by offering a much longer term LTRO. Something in the region of a 7 or 10 year. After that comes QE. Yes I know there are potential legal challenges to such a move but I do believe Mr Draghi when he says he will do whatever it takes and don’t forget that at the ECB press conference of 2nd August 2012 (just after Spanish 2 years hit 7% and he gave his ‘Whatever it takes’ speech) he said that ‘…the Governing Council may undertake may consider undertaking further non-standard monetary policy measures…’ and then in the Q and A section discussing what became the OMT he said that ‘Regarding sterilisation, you should not assume that we are not going to sterilise or that we will sterilise – you have to understand these operations (the setting up of the OMT) are complex and they affect markets in a variety of ways. So the relevant committees will have to work and tell us exactly what is right and what is not, so it is too early to say whether they are going to be sterilised or not sterilised…’

So even though it didn’t happen then, QE was on the agenda, which makes me think it could well be on the agenda again if the ECB believes that deflation could be about to take hold.

ECB rate cut, the key points

A quick summary of the key points from the ECB press conference (highlights start here)

• The European Central Bank has suggested that euro interest rates could be cut still further, after slashing borrowing costs to a new record low of 0.25%.

The governing council reiterated its forward guidance that borrowing costs will remain at their present or lower levels for an 'extended period of time', and pledged that "our monetary policy stance will remain accommodative for as long as necessary."

Britain's City watchdog, the Financial Conduct Authority, has now written to bank bosses, urging them to speed up the process. It says it is " frustrated" that the compensation process is proceeding so slowly. 

The banks need to hurry up -- around 30,000 firms are though to have lost out after buying protection against interest rate rises.

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and the business world.

It's a big day for central bank news, with the Bank of England and the European Central Bank both announcing their monthly decisions on monetary policy. And I suspect the atmosphere will be quite different in London than in Frankfurt.

The ECB must decide whether to cut rates, or ease monetary conditions in some other way, in response to signs that the euro economy is de-inflating as the recovery loses momentum.

Few economists actually expect a cut to the headline borrowing rate at 12.45pm GMT today (although it's certainly possible), but the subsequent press conference with Mario Draghi (1.30pm GMT) will be closely watched.

He may set the scene for a rate cut in December, for example. Another option would be to impose 'negative interest rates' on the eurozone banks, to encourage them to lend more.

The pressure is on the ECB after core consumer price inflation unexpectedly fell last week, and unemployment hit a new record high. This prompted much concern that the eurozone is slipping into a Japan-style slump.

Although there's only so much that even the president of the ECB can do to fix the euro area's troubles:

At Threadneedle Street, though, the Bank of England will have the luxury of looking at an economy that appears to be on the up.

fields.bodyText: And that's a good moment to stop for the night. Thanks all. GW Analysts have been digesting the ECB's surprise interest rate cut, and Mario Draghi's press conference performance (highlights start here....with a summary here) Here's a selection. Jessica Hinds of Capital Economics: Thursday’s rate cut reinforces the divergent stances of monetary policy in the euro-zone and the US. The ECB has just eased policy even further, while the Fed, for all its procrastinating, is still more than likely to scale back its asset purchases before too long. Furthermore, President Draghi added that rates could go even lower and that the ECB was “technically ready” to cut its deposit rate into negative territory. Meanwhile, we do not expect the strength of peripheral euro-zone government bonds to last just because the ECB has become more accommodative. A small cut to the refi rate will not transform the economic outlook and will not address the deep-seated problems of the peripheral countries such as their high debt burdens. Indeed, credit spreads on euro-zone peripheral government bonds have fallen all the way back to the sort of levels seen on comparably-rated assets outside the euro-zone. There would therefore appear to be a significant risk of a renewed rise in them over time if and when investors’ concerns about these problems reappear. Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities 1) One has to always doff one's hat to Draghi for his ability to "blag a blagger", in rather stark (sic) contrast to his predecessors, and the conservative Bundesbank type grouping on the council. 2) The timing for a rate cut is/was always key, and so the decision to "go now" rather than roll out the red carpet for December made good sense.... but that unfortunately is where the compliments stop. 3) So to the rationale: the ECB is now expecting a "sustained period of low inflation", but sees "no risk of deflation" - really? a) Does the ECB has any control over such a fine dividing line, given that Eurozone CPI is 0.7% y/y? b) One might even ask whether the ECB is wondering into the BoE's bad forecasting territory? and c) What happened to that recent suggestion that a very low level of inflation was in fact good for (hard pressed) Eurozone (above all Club Med) consumers? 4) While he could say nothing else other than that he "believes rate cut is effective" to then follow it up with "some would say reduction in excess liquidity is due to less fragmentation" and, that the rate cut "reduces fragmentation in the periphery" is pushing on a gossamer thin bit of string, the more so when he continued later with this particular bit of bravado: "fundamentals in the Eurozone are probably strongest in the world", while saying that the recovery is "proceeding, but is weak and fragile". Which epithet of these would be best to deploy: a) paradox, b) oxymoron or c) bipolar? 5) What will this do for growth in the Eurozone economy, employment, indeed bank lending - not a lot. The fact is that by cutting the income of savers, and in fact discouraging bank lending by keeping long-term rates at very depressed levels, as well as tying to persuade businesses and consumers that they actually do not need act now to "lock in" super low rates, the ECB, Fed and BoE may in fact be depressing the economy, while exponentially fuelling asset bubbles and widening economic and social gaps. Mike Ingram of BGC Partners: Cut and Run at the ECB What a shocker. The market had assumed, at most, a one in ten chance of the European Central Bank (ECB) cutting rates today and yet they did just that. The ECB refinancing rate was halved to 0.25%. For today at least, European stock and bonds were euphoric and the overly strong Euro has taken a beating. Mission accomplished Mr Draghi. In actuality, a rate cut has only been a question of ‘when’ rather than ‘if’ for some time now. Euro zone inflation is collapsing while output gaps are large and with feeble growth, set to be persistent. Moreover credit conditions are still tightening, albeit at a slower pace and little progress has been made in bringing down lending rates in Europe’s beleaguered periphery. To top it all, the Euro has been strong – defying the consensus call of a strong dollar. Taken together, I wasn’t kidding when I recently suggested that large swathes of the Euro zone are becoming eerily reminiscent of 1990’s Japan. And yet most of us have been wrong-footed today. (I included, I thought the Bank would wait for more data before cutting in December). In defence I can only say that even as the economic case for a rate cut became compelling, Team Draghi seem infuriatingly relaxed about the need to ease policy further. Now they have belatedly leapt into action. So for many reasons, I approached the recently concluded ECB press conference with more than a little curiosity. And while it was another polished performance from Super Mario, I wasn’t greatly comforted by what I heard either. I am now left feeling that while the ECB may no longer be horribly behind the curve, there is little chance they are ahead of it and it is only a matter of time before they are playing catch up again. It could have been worse of course; a late cut is better than none at all. One on the big positives was that, despite cutting rates to an all-time low, we learned that the ECB ‘continues to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time’. It could easily have signalled that rates at 0.25% were an effective floor, but it didn’t. Moreover, it emerged in the Q&A that such forward guidance was unanimous. The ECB feels it still has a few rate cards left to play. But this seemingly definitive statement of central bank activism sits uneasily with much else that the ECB had to say this afternoon. For instance, the Euro zone inflation outlook was once again described as ‘broadly balanced’. It clearly hasn’t been in the past and given significant deflationary headwinds, I suspect this remains a mistaken prognosis. Of more practical concern to most of us is that the ECB’s take on the nascent Euro zone economic recovery also seems threadbare. Having shifted the supposed growth drivers from exports and investment early in the year, to consumption and investment in the summer (as emerging markets swooned and PMIs picked up), it is now apparently all down to consumption. Presumably this belatedly recognises that businesses in the Euro zone remain loathe to invest. Hardly a surprise given ample spare capacity and in many cases continued credit rationing. They are more likely to bolster profits by squeezing employees. If so, sayonara consumption too! Perhaps the most disturbing part of the ECB’s performance today however, was a seemingly off the cuff remark that Mario Draghi made on the long-term outlook for the Euro zone economy. The Euro zone, he said, ‘had some of the best fundamentals in the world’. (I actually laughed out loud at that point). Mario then proceeded to reel off this secret recipe for economic success: low budget deficits and current account surpluses. I’m sure Angela Merkel must have been overjoyed, but it strikes me that if the main thrust of economic policy is that the rest of Europe deflates against an already competitive Germany, then the outlook for Europe is grim indeed. At that point the ECB’s hand may be looking quite poor – if the market doesn’t call their bluff first. Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research So after spending a good part of the last 18 months stating that Europe would be experiencing uplift in economic fortunes right about now Mr Draghi has had to cut rates today. I found it an unconvincing and contradictory performance in the press conference and found it especially interesting that Mr Draghi basically ignored two questions on QE. The big question is what can the ECB do next if the worrying recent trends with regard to loan demand and inflation do not reverse. Mr Draghi stated that he had a whole range of instruments left to deal with any deteriorating situation, but the ones he mentioned were very much interest rate options. Cheap money has not yet produced any uptick in loan demand in Europe and it is difficult to see why this should change whether he alters the benchmark rate, the deposit rate or whatever. Banks continue to be in deleveraging mode and companies are not confident enough of the immediate economic outlook to invest. Thus if the ECB rate cuts do not stimulate loan growth or reverse falling prices then what do they do next? I think the first port of call would be to try and encourage banks to lend by offering a much longer term LTRO. Something in the region of a 7 or 10 year. After that comes QE. Yes I know there are potential legal challenges to such a move but I do believe Mr Draghi when he says he will do whatever it takes and don’t forget that at the ECB press conference of 2nd August 2012 (just after Spanish 2 years hit 7% and he gave his ‘Whatever it takes’ speech) he said that ‘…the Governing Council may undertake may consider undertaking further non-standard monetary policy measures…’ and then in the Q and A section discussing what became the OMT he said that ‘Regarding sterilisation, you should not assume that we are not going to sterilise or that we will sterilise – you have to understand these operations (the setting up of the OMT) are complex and they affect markets in a variety of ways. So the relevant committees will have to work and tell us exactly what is right and what is not, so it is too early to say whether they are going to be sterilised or not sterilised…’ So even though it didn’t happen then, QE was on the agenda, which makes me think it could well be on the agenda again if the ECB believes that deflation could be about to take hold. And if that isn't enough...there's even more reaction on FT Alphaville: Another photo from Greece tonight: On Twitter's stock market debut, our Wall Street correspondent Dominic Rushe writes: Twitter made a spectacular debut on the New York stock exchange Thursday as its share price soared, initially valuing the company at over $31bn. The company set a share price of $26 on Tuesday but fierce bidding for the limited number of shares available drove that price up to $45.10 as the stock market opened, a rise of 73%. In early trading, the price increased even further. At $31bn, Twitter – a loss-making firm – is 10 times more valuable than the original internet darling AOL. The price is equivalent to that of Yum Brands, owner of Taco Bell, KFC, Pizza Hut, which manages or owns 39,000 restaurants worldwide and made a profit of over $1.3bn last year. Twitter share price opens at $45.10 as value surges on Wall Street debut Significant developments in Greece tonight -- the opposition Syriza party has submitted a censure motion over the police raid on ERT's headquarters (as covered way back at 8am). According to reports from Athens, a vote of confidence could be held on Sunday night. Syriza leader Alexis Tsipras laid into prime minister Antonis Samaras over the affair. The Kathimerini newspaper reports: Speaking in Parliament, Tsipras said the government had "no popular mandate" for its policies. Administrative Reform Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who is overseeing a civil service overhaul, accepted Tsipras' motion, saying it would give the government an opportunity to prove that its parliamentary majority is strong. The New Democracy-PASOK coalition has 155 deputies in the 300-seat House. So it would take a rebellion from several NS and Pasok MPs for the government to lose the vote..... While the ECB press conference was taking place, protesters were holding a rally in Athens. Hundreds of people demonstrated against the decision to sent riot police into the headquarters of the former Greek Public Broadcaster (ERT). Here's some photos: Back to the eurozone, and the International Monetary Fund has joined the ranks of those welcoming today's ECB rate cut. IMF spokesman Gerry Rice told reporters that: The decision is fully warranted by the weak inflation dynamics and substantial slack in the economy. Over in New York, Twitter is finally trading -- with an almighty pop. Shares were sold at $26 each, and opened at $45.10 -- a stonking increase of over 70%. My US colleague Adam Gabbatt is tracking all the action here: Twitter IPO -– live coverage A quick summary of the key points from the ECB press conference (highlights start here) • The European Central Bank has suggested that euro interest rates could be cut still further, after slashing borrowing costs to a new record low of 0.25%. The governing council reiterated its forward guidance that borrowing costs will remain at their present or lower levels for an 'extended period of time', and pledged that "our monetary policy stance will remain accommodative for as long as necessary." • ECB president Mario Draghi warned that the eurozone faces a prolonged period of low inflation. He denied, though, that there is a real risk of deflation gripping the area. • The decision was not fully unanimous, Draghi revealed, with some members of the committee arguing to wait until December. • Draghi also rejected suggestions that the euro area is sinking into Japanification. Instead, it has the best fundamentals in the world, he claimed. Not everyone is convinced..... • The rate cut has already been welcomed by the Italian prime minister and the French finance minister. • The euro remains weaker today, down over 1% against the US dollar at $1.3374 and 0.7% lower against sterling. Stock markets welcomed the cut, with European shares hitting new five-year highs. France's finance minister says it is "good news" that eurozone interest rates have been cut to a new record low. Pierre Moscovici tweeted that the rate cut was welcome support for the ongoing recovery in the eurozone, and should lower the risk of deflation. Haven't seen any reaction from Germany yet.... That's the end of the ECB press conference. And better late than never, here's a link to Mario Draghi's opening statement explaining why the ECB cut rates: Introductory statement to the press conference. First, based on our regular economic and monetary analyses, we decided to lower the interest rate on the main refinancing operations of the Eurosystem by 25 basis points to 0.25% and the rate on the marginal lending facility by 25 basis points to 0.75%. The rate on the deposit facility will remain unchanged at 0.00%. These decisions are in line with our forward guidance of July 2013, given the latest indications of further diminishing underlying price pressures in the euro area over the medium term, starting from currently low annual inflation rates of below 1%. In keeping with this picture, monetary and, in particular, credit dynamics remain subdued. At the same time, inflation expectations for the euro area over the medium to long term continue to be firmly anchored in line with our aim of maintaining inflation rates below, but close to, 2%. Such a constellation suggests that we may experience a prolonged period of low inflation, to be followed by a gradual upward movement towards inflation rates below, but close to, 2% later on. Accordingly, our monetary policy stance will remain accommodative for as long as necessary. It will thereby also continue to assist the gradual economic recovery as reflected in confidence indicators up to October. Mario Draghi's declaration that the eurozone has the best economic fundamentals in the world may come back to haunt him, ECB-watchers suggest: In other news, a team from Twitter including actor Sir Patrick Stewart just rang the opening bell on Wall Street. Full coverage here: Twitter IPO: live coverage Is the deflation threat in the eurozone similar to Japan? No, replies Mario Draghi. I don't think so. He reminds the press conference that the eurozone crisis started with the region's banks being overleveraged, with many bad assets. In some countries, both deficits and debts needed to come down. Thus the need for fiscal consolidation. He then declares the eurozone's fundamentals are "probably the strongest in the world". This is a zone that has the lowest budget deficit in the world..... It has the highest current account surplus. And it has one of the lowest inflation rates. This does not translate into a "galloping recovery" but it creates a platform to build a recovery on, he insists. Take that, eurozone doubters. Was the euro's strength against the US dollar a factor in today's decision? Draghi denies that the issue was even discussed. Exchange rates are not a policy target, he insists. He adde that the rate cut will reduce fragmentation across the eurozone (ie, the fact that borrowing costs in parts of the euro area are higher than others). Progress on fragmentation appears to have stalled recently, he adds. Today's cut will help healthy banks in the periphery to get better access to funds, he adds. Back to the ECB press conference, Mario Draghi is asked about the prospect of Ireland leaving its bailout programme without a precautionary credit line (a safety net for its return to the financial markets) He replies that Ireland should be congratulated for completing its financial aid programme (as reported before noon in the blog, it has passed its final Troika inspection today). The decision on whether to take a precautionary credit line is entirely up to Dublin's government, he adds. The ECB won't interfere. Italian prime minister Enrico Letta has declared that the eurozone interest rate cut is "great news" and shows that the ECB understands the need for growth (via Reuters) A question about whether the financial markets were unprepared for today's announcement. And has Draghi produced an anti-tank weapon, rather than the pea-shooter that Kit Juckes mentioned this morning. Mario Draghi declines to comment on the market reaction, as they "do what they want" . He also declares that the credibility of the ECB's forward guidance has been "strengthened" by today's decision, urging economists to take another look at last month's statement. Draghi explains that it's important to have low real interest rates to help the fragile recovery. It is also much harder to make much-needed reforms and get monetary measures to work if inflation is significantly below 2%. Quite a complicated answer on the issue of liquidity in the euro area.... Will a rate cut really do any good? Draghi says he believes the rate cut will be effective, and there are signs of it already being effective (the drop in the value of the euro?) It will help lending to businesses and households, and push down real interest rates, he pledges. Was the decision unanimous? Apparently not! Draghi says the governing council was "Wholly in agreement about the need to act, but there were disagreements about when to act". A majority pushed for action today, while others wanted to wait for next month's data for additional information. On the forward guidance, there was unanimity, he adds. Was Jens Weidmann of the Bundesbank one of those who wanted to wait, we wonder... Reuters asks whether the ECB considered cutting its deposit lending rate into negative territory (meaning banks would have to pay to leave money in its electronic vaults). Draghi says that the governing council certainly discussed it, and stands ready to act if needed. We want to have some instruments in our artillery, and that is certainty one, he adds. A new long-term LTRO* was not discussed in any detail, though. * - a long-term offering of cheap loans First question goes to Bloomberg -- How long will this prolonged period of low inflation be, and will it fall lower, closer towards deflation? And what tools does the ECB have to fight deflation? Draghi says inflation will be low for some period of time...."it certainly won't be a short period of time" (so not much clarity there!). We'll get more details at the next ECB forecasts in December, he promises. The ECB does not see a "self fulfilling decline in prices across goods and countries", though, he adds. Onto the Q&A.... Governments must implement structural reforms in labour markets too, Draghi says -- to help push down jobless levels and improve competitiveness. Draghi concludes his statement with his regular warning that eurozone governments should not ease the pace of reforms. Draghi makes some interesting points on the state of the eurozone banking sector. Loan dynamics remain weak, reflecting the state of the business cycle. It is essential that banks are strengthened, and fragmentation across banking sector is reduced, says Draghi. He adds that the ECB's new stress tests of eurozone banks should help to rebuild confidence in the sector.... Following today's rate cuts, the risks to eurozone inflation are 'broadly balanced' says Draghi, as he reiterates that inflation may remain low for a prolonged period of time. Draghi is explaining that while the eurozone economy is finally growing again after 18 months of recession, it remains weak and vulnerable. He cited several threats -- global money market conditions, higher commodity prices, weak domestic demand, disappointing exports, and insufficient progress on economic reforms by eurozone governments. The full statement will be online soon. Draghi reiterates that eurozone borrowing costs will remain at their present or lower levels until conditions improve -- suggesting a further cut below 0.25% is still possible. Monetary policy stance will remain accommodative for as long as necessary, basically. He also states that the ECB stands ready to continue all available instruments. The ECB will continue to conduct its three-month LTROS (lending to eurozone banks) until at least the end of the second quarter of 2015. The eurozone may experience "a prolonged period of low inflation", Draghi warns, followed by a gradual return back to the target of close to, but below 2%. Monetary and credit dynamics remain subdued, says Draghi, while inflation expectations are firmly anchored. Mario Draghi's press conference is underway, with the ECB president saying the ECB governing council took a number of decisions at today's meeting. He confirms that interest rates have been cut, saying it is 'in line' with the ECB's forward guidance on interest rate policy. Newsflash: US GDP rose by 2.8% on an annualised basis in the third quarter of 2013 - higher than expected. Mario Draghi is about to sitting down to meet the press in Frankfurt, and explain why the ECB cut interest rates. The press conference will be streamed live here, and on Bloomberg TV. Here's our news story on the ECB rate cut, by Heather Stewart: Borrowers across the struggling eurozone economies received an unexpected fillip on Thursday when the European Central Bank cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, in a bid to stave off a slide into deflation. After its monthly policy meeting in Frankfurt, the ECB's governing council announced that it would reduce its key refinancing rate to 0.25%, from 0.5%. More here: ECB surprises markets by cutting eurozone interest rates to 0.25% More reaction to the ECB rate cut. Jonathan Loynes of Capital Economics: (via Reuters) The ECB’s decision to cut interest rates is a pleasant surprise given the Governing Council’s previous insensitivity to the growing risks of deflation in the region – some members felt just last month that the case for a rate cut was not even worth discussing! The press conference ... may offer the prospect of more policy action, perhaps including more LTROs. But the ECB alone cannot address the deep-seated problems still facing the single currency union. Neil Williams, chief economist at Hermes Fund Managers: Draghi’s pledge last year to “do whatever it takes” may continue to cap funding costs (a symptom), but will do little to address the underlying problem: disparate competitiveness across a monetary union with insufficient economic union. We doubt any sudden volte-face from Germany on fiscal/banking union. We are more concerned about Spain’s dilemma: where fiscal inertia means funding strains; yet, approaching 60% male youth unemployment, any meaningful reform risks social unrest. Here's a round-up of instant reaction to the ECB interest rate cut: Carsten Brzeski of ING: Deflationary risks and the stronger euro seem to have motivated the ECB’s move. It is obvious that the ECB under president Draghi has become much more pro-active than under any of his predecessors. Let’s now wait for the press conference to see whether Draghi has more surprises to offer. David Nicholls, alliance manager at UKForex, said: It is a bold move, and further demonstrates the ECB’s resolve to use any means necessary to get growth back into Europe and ensure any existing momentum does not wane from the fragile Eurozone recovery. Although some commentators were foreseeing this move it has caught the market off guard with GBP/EUR moving up over 1.2 and EUR/USD crashing 2 cents to 1.3370. The euro’s status as a safe haven bet against the dollar is rapidly being lost. Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight: The ECB’s decision to cut its key interest from 0.50% to 0.25% is obviously the consequence of uncomfortably low and falling Eurozone consumer price inflation. The ECB’s mandate is for a Eurozone consumer price inflation rate of “close to but just below 2.0%”, and at just 0.7% in October the inflation rate is no longer at a level that can be seen as consistent with the ECB;s target rate. Furthermore, the ECB’s forward guidance that has been in place since July stated that “the Governing Council expects the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time.” If the ECB had not reacted to Eurozone consumer price inflation dropping to just 0.7% in October by cutting interest rates, it could have led the markets to questioning how meaningful the ECB’s forward guidance was. While the drop in Eurozone consumer price inflation to just 0.7 in October was obviously the trigger for the ECB’s interest rate cut, the strength of the euro and only gradual Eurozone economic recovery from extended recession also supported the case for lower interest rates. The fact that the ECB chose to act now rather than wait until December when the Governing Council will have the ECB staff’s new Eurozone GDP and consumer price inflation forecasts suggests that the bank felt there was a compelling case for prompt action. The fact that the ECB chose to leave its deposit rate unchanged at 0.0% despite bringing the refinancing rate down from 0.50% to 0.25% reinforces our belief that the ECB is reluctant to go down the negative deposit rate route. However, this could still happen if there is not a marked pick up in bank lending to companies and the ECB struggles to develop recovery. While it seems unlikely that an interest rate cut to 0.25% would have a major impact in boosting Eurozone growth, it may at least help keep the euro at a more competitive level and limit market interest rates. Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital: ECB chief Mario Draghi today showed he is quite different from former ECB head Trichet, pulling out a surprise like this from time to time. High unemployment in the region also another likely contributor to today’s rate cut – markets are now eyeing Draghi’s press conference for further insight into the decision. The tone of the conference is likely to be dovish with Draghi justifying the move which has knocked the euro currency sharply lower against rivals. A big question for the market is how effective is this rate cut really? Conditions in the euro zone are likely to see a meaningful change after this rate cut – it seems more of a demonstration by the ECB to move away from liquidity pumping measures to measures which will ensure sustainable growth feeding into the real economy. The move therefore could be more symbolic of the ECB’s evolving strategy to stimulate the euro zone economy. Earlier, the BOE kept policies unchanged, as expected – muted response in markets. Eyes are now firmly on Draghi for more So why did the European Central Bank cut interest rates to a new record low of just 0.25%? The eurozone's central bank acted after inflation slumped to just 0.7% in October, well below its target of just under 2%. This morning's news of deflation in Ireland may have encouraged it to act. Private sector firms have also reported that activity grew at a slower rate in October than September, suggesting the recovery from recession was faltering. With unemployment at a record high of 12.2%, and many countries suffering from the impact of austerity, the ECB's governing council has concluded that monetary policy should be eased. webTitle: Morrisons' boss breaks ranks by being optimistic

fields.bodyText: That's the spirit – a big retail boss who is prepared to say when his soggy sales numbers will turn positive. Going where Marks & Spencer's Marc Bolland feared to tread on clothing, Morrisons' Dalton Philips predicted on Thursday that a run of seven successive declines in the supermarket chain's quarterly like-for-like sales is about to end. The turnaround will happen in the Christmas quarter, said Philips. On the (usually reliable) principle that bosses set public targets only when they know they can be met, the forecast looks safe. It is not hard to guess why Morrisons thinks it can go from minus 2.4% in the third quarter to a positive figure in a single jump. Unlike M&S in clothing, Morrisons enjoys the benefit of new, and maturing, space starting to contribute towards the like-for-like readings; the group has had its foot to the pedal on convenience stores in recent years. It will also crank up promotional activity, a factor that was missing during the summer. And the recent industry-wide sales data showed Morrisons gaining share in October. Besides, it had a shocker last Christmas. Jolly good, so has the Philips medicine – tighter management, more convenience stores and a belated launch into online via a partnership with Ocado – worked? It's too early to say that, since the online venture will be launched only in January. But one can say that Philips intends to arrive in home delivery with a splash, promising that by the end of next year Morrisons will be able to serve 50% of UK homes, including London. That implies a lot of extra online capacity coming on stream in a hurry. For the supermarket industry as a whole, the big question remains unanswered: when you are delivering to punters' homes for a £5 charge, a rate that looks uneconomic, how can profit margins in the old-style stores be sustained? Once he has delivered the Christmas revival, there's Philips' next challenge.

webTitle: Superdry parent company announces another sales rise

fields.bodyText: The company behind the Superdry fashion label has unveiled another leap in sales – its eighth consecutive quarter of growth – as improved women's ranges and international expansion attracted new customers. Like-for-like retail sales at Supergroup, which also operates the Cult chain of fashion outlets, were up 7.8% in the most recent three months. Over the last six months total group sales rose 21.1% to £192m. Founder and chief executive Julian Dunkerton said: "We really are getting a momentum behind the business and the biggest driver behind that is the product. We're getting a better all over range." He said the biggest improvement had been achieved in womenswear, with new ranges attracting a "new consumer". The trading update was in stark contrast to results published earlier in the week by Marks & Spencer, which showed a 1.3% fall in like-for-like clothing and homewares sales in the second quarter. Cheltenham-based SuperGroup opened three new UK stores over the quarter, and acquired two franchise stores. The company, established in 1985, now sells to online customers in more than 100 countries, with international internet sales outpacing those in the UK. "We are a great British export story and will continue to focus on that," Dunkerton said. He added that the outlook for the company was positive. "I'm fairly confident that consumer confidence is returning. If you have a clearly defined product that consumers get, they will come." The shares rose 1.6% to 1226p – up from 550p at the turn of this year.

webTitle: Morrisons set for first rise in quarterly sales for two years, says chief executive

fields.standfirst: Dalton Philips expects market to remain challenging but says retailer has good momentum since launch of Christmas offers
fields.body:
Morrisons is hoping to deliver its first upturn in trade for two years over the coming weeks, despite a further slump in the past three months.

Chief executive Dalton Philips said the market was likely to remain challenging in the run-up to Christmas as shoppers had less cash to spend than last year, but he insisted the Bradford-based supermarket was on an "improving trend" since launching its seasonal offers, including a bonus scheme to reward loyal shoppers.

"We know it is going to be a competitive market – it always is at this time of year. But we are feeling more comfortable with our direction of travel and have a certain level of confidence as we go into this quarter," he said.

Britain's fourth biggest supermarket blamed a challenging backdrop and strong competition from rivals for a 2.4% fall in third-quarter like-for-like sales, which strip out the impact of new store openings. Philips blamed most of that decline on the fact that Morrisons does not yet have an online delivery service or a large number of convenience stores. Total sales – which include gains from new space – were up 1% over the 13 weeks to 3 November.

Analysts said that, with price inflation at 2.5% to 3%, Morrisons was seeing a drop in the amount of goods bought by its shoppers, and this would put pressure on its profits.

Clive Black, an analyst at Shore Capital, said Morrisons' hope of better sales over Christmas would be boosted by comparison with a weak trading period last year and plans to open stores on Boxing Day and New Year's Day for the first time.

He said: "The heat is certainly on for management to deliver a material improvement in across-the-board sales growth over the important Christmas period."

Philips said that a relaunch of own-label products and an "uplifting" ad campaign featuring celebrities Ant and Dec would drive positive sales growth over the next three months.

Morrisons will begin an online delivery service in Warwickshire from January 2014, as it becomes the last of the major grocers to open an internet store.

The service, in partnership with Ocado, will then be rolled out to Yorkshire, and by the end of 2014 more than half of the UK's households, including London, should be able to order online.

Morrisons is also attempting to boost its position in the fast-growing convenience store sector by opening three small M Local stores a week.

The company opened 36 of these during the quarter, bringing the total to 69 across the UK. Around half of the M Local stores are in London and the south-east, which the Yorkshire-based retailer is targeting for growth. It plans to have a total of 100 M Local stores open by the end of the financial year, and 200 by the end of the following year.

webTitle: Former Barclays chairman on payroll until March 2014

fields.standfirst: Marcus Agius remains in consultancy role for undisclosed fee, having resigned in July 2012 after Libor fine
fields.body:
Marcus Agius is to remain on the Barclays payroll until March next year – 20 months after resigning as chairman of the troubled bank.

He quit his £750,000 role on 2 July 2012, just days after the bank was thrown into turmoil in the aftermath of its £290m fine for attempting to rig Libor. But he was forced into a U-turn the next day after regulators forced out Bob Diamond, the chief executive, instead.

Agius stayed until the end of October when he was replaced by Sir David Walker. The bank later revealed that he had been retained on a 12-month £175,000 consultancy contract to provide what was described as advisory support for the corporate banking arm.

In the annual report released in March the bank said this one-year arrangement would be reviewed "in light of business generated". He is now to remain with the bank until March 2014, with continued use of the bank's town house in the West End of London, intended for the bank's wealthiest clients.

It is not clear how much he will be paid for the remaining five months of his consultancy.

Agius was one of the best known investment bankers in the City – he spent 35 years with Lazards – when he was appointed to the board of Barclays in 2006, becoming chairman in January the following year.

His wife, Kate, is the daughter of Edmund de Rothschild, of the Rothschild banking family.

His tenure coincided with the 2007 credit crunch and the 2008 banking crisis, when the bank caused controversy by turning to Middle Eastern investors for a £7bn life-saving cash call instead of taking a taxpayer bailout.

Agius also had to tackle rebellions by shareholders over pay deals for Diamond, and the bank's pay policies.

His testimony to the Treasury select committee in the days after the Libor fine caused shockwaves: he revealed that on the day he announced his resignation he had been summoned by the then governor of the Bank of England, Lord King, to be told that Diamond no longer had the support of the regulator.

Many City sources believe that Agius resigned to try to protect Diamond after the bank had been caught out by the public and political reaction to the Libor fine.

Since then, regulators have levied bigger fines on Royal Bank of Scotland, UBS of Switzerland and the Dutch bank Rabobank for attempting to manipulate the key benchmark interest rate, while the money broker Icap has also been fined.

Other firms remain under investigation by the Financial Conduct Authority and there have been reports that EU competition authorities are preparing to fine a number of banks, including Barclays, for rigging other benchmark rates.

Barclays, now run by Antony Jenkins who was promoted after Diamond left, admitted last week it is now co-operating with regulators on a new investigation into whether the £3tn-a-day currency markets have been manipulated.

The investigation is at an early stage, although some in the City believe that it could eventually be on the same scale as the Libor-rigging scandal.

webTitle: ECB surprises markets by cutting eurozone interest rates to 0.25%

fields.bodyText: Borrowers across the struggling eurozone economies received an unexpected fillip on Thursday when the European Central Bank cut interest rates to a fresh record low, in a bid to stave off a slide into deflation. After its monthly policy meeting in Frankfurt, the ECB's governing council announced that it would reduce its key refinancing rate to 0.25%, from 0.5%. While the economy of the 18-member single currency area clambered out of recession earlier this year, Mario Draghi, the ECB's president, warned that the outlook could deteriorate in the coming months. "The risks surrounding the economic outlook for the euro area continue to be on the downside," he said. "Developments in global money and financial market conditions and related uncertainties may have the potential to negatively affect economic conditions. Other downside risks include higher commodity prices, weaker than expected domestic demand and export growth, and slow or insufficient implementation of structural reforms in euro area countries." As well as the rate cut, which took financial markets by surprise, Draghi said the ECB would continue making low-cost loans to eurozone banks until at least mid-2015, to try to prevent the financial sector from seizing up. Howard Archer, of consultancy IHS Global Insight, said: "The fact that the ECB chose to act now rather than wait until December when the governing council will have the ECB staff's new eurozone GDP and consumer price inflation forecasts suggests that the bank felt there was a compelling case for prompt action." With inflation running well below the ECB's 2% target, at just 0.7% in October, a growing number of analysts have started to warn that deflation – which can be disastrous for economies carrying a heavy debt burden, as prices and wages fall while debt-levels remain fixed – is a real threat. Draghi suggested at his press conference that, "we may experience a prolonged period of low inflation". The recent strength of the euro against the dollar has also raised fears in some member-countries about the competitiveness of the zone's exports on world markets. The euro was down by more than 1% against most major currencies after Thursday's announcement, hitting a seven-week low of $1.3375 against the dollar.Italian prime minister Enrico Letta, speaking on a visit to Dublin, described the ECB's decision as "great news", adding that, "it shows the ECB cares about growth and competitiveness in Europe". The International Monetary Fund also welcomed the move. "The decision is fully warranted by the weak inflation dynamics and substantial slack in the economy," said spokesman Gerry Rice. The muted strength of the economic recovery in many eurozone countries is likely to have been another factor influencing the ECB's decision: earlier this week, the European commission revised down its expectation for growth across the 18 member-countries to just 1.1% in 2014. Nevertheless, Draghi insisted at his Frankfurt press conference that the "fundamentals" of the eurozone are, "probably the strongest in the world". However, some analysts warned that the rate cut should be no substitute for the urgent reforms the eurozone needs to secure recovery and tackle the legacy of unmanageable government debts. "It's a palliative: a legal high," said Danny Gabay, of City consultancy Fathom. "They need to get on with the really important stuff: fiscal union, banking reform, debt mutualisation." The ECB's move is unlikely to prove popular in Germany, where the Bundesbank – whose president, Jens Weidmann, sits on the ECB's governing council – has tended to take a hawkish stance, opposing some of the ECB's recession-busting measures. Draghi admitted that Thursday's decision had not been unanimous, saying the governing council was, "wholly in agreement about the need to act, but there were disagreements about when to act". The suprise rate cut was the fifth since Draghi took over from the more orthodox Jean-Claude Trichet in 2011. The decision followed an earlier announcement from the Bank of England that it will leave its own interest rate unchanged at 0.5%, and the total value of assets held under QE at £375bn.

webTitle: ECB cuts interest rates: what the experts say

fields.standfirst: Economists give their reaction to the European Central Bank's cut in interest rates to a record low of 0.25%
fields.body:
Nick Kounis, ABN Amro

We expected the ECB to cut rates in December, when its new projections would be available. Although the timing of the move is a surprise, the case for a rate reduction was overwhelming in our view. Inflation is already well below the ECB's price stability goal, while disinflationary pressures remain.

We expect headline inflation to fall further in the coming months and it is likely to significantly undershoot the ECB's price stability goal over the next two years. This reflects that the economy is recovering, but slowly, following a long period of weakness when substantial economic slack has built up.

The low rates of inflation leave the single currency area vulnerable, and this is a risk the ECB simply cannot ignore. It may well need to go further. The next step is likely to be a strengthening of its forward guidance.

Stephen Lewis, Monument Securities

It's more surprising in the timing than the direction. One might have expected the ECB to wait until it published its next set of economic forecasts. Clearly, most of the people sitting around that table deciding policy feel that they have enough information to make this move.

They probably feel that if they delay it, they would be open to criticism if the inflation rate were to fall even further than this.

Howard Archer, IHS Global Insight

The ECB's decision to cut its key interest to 0.25% is obviously the consequence of uncomfortably low and falling eurozone consumer price inflation.

The ECB's mandate is for a eurozone consumer price inflation rate of "close to but just below 2.0%", and at just 0.7% in October the inflation rate is no longer at a level that can be seen as consistent with the ECB's target rate.

While the drop in eurozone consumer price inflation was obviously the trigger for the ECB's interest rate cut, the strength of the euro and only gradual eurozone economic recovery from recession also supported the case for lower interest rates.

The fact that the ECB chose to act now rather than wait until December when the governing council will have the ECB's new eurozone GDP and consumer price inflation forecasts suggests that the bank felt there was a compelling case for prompt action.

That the bank chose to leave its deposit rate unchanged at 0.0% despite bringing the refinancing rate down reinforces our belief that the ECB is reluctant to go down the negative deposit rate route. However, this could still happen if there is not a marked pickup in banks lending to companies and the ECB struggles to develop recovery.

While it seems unlikely that this interest rate cut will have a major impact in boosting eurozone growth, it may at least help keep the euro at a more competitive level and limit market interest rates.

Carsten Brzeski, ING

The ECB surprised most analysts, including us. Deflationary risks and the stronger euro seem to have motivated its move. It is obvious that the ECB under President [Mario] Draghi has become much more proactive than under any of his predecessors. Let's now wait for the press conference to see whether Draghi has more surprises to offer.

Jonathan Loynes, Capital Economics

The ECB's decision to cut interest rates is a pleasant surprise given the governing council's previous insensitivity to the growing risks of deflation in the region. Some members felt just last month that the case for a rate cut was not even worth discussing.

The combination of October's unexpectedly large fall in consumer price inflation to just 0.7%, the strength of the euro exchange rate and growing concerns over liquidity conditions in the banking sector appears to have persuaded most members that some sort of reaction was necessary.

That said, the cut to 0.25% is clearly not going to transform the outlook for the economy on its own, particularly as the council shied away from imposing a negative deposit rate in attempt to stimulate bank lending.

There may be some near-term downward pressure on the euro exchange rate, but from a very high level which today's German IP figures suggest might already be slowing the recovery in the region. And with the ECB now surely out of interest rate ammo and still reluctant to engage in quantitative easing, even the currency effect might not last very long.

The ECB alone cannot address the deep-seated problems still facing the single currency union.

webTitle: Rise in US economic growth brings tapering back into focus

fields.bodyText: America's economy grew at a faster-than-expected 2.8% annual rate in the third quarter of 2013, raising the prospect that the Federal Reserve could start to phase out its recession-busting quantitative easing programme before Ben Bernanke bows out in January. Wall Street analysts had expected the world's largest economy to slow between July and September from the 2.5% pace recorded in the second quarter. But in a keenly awaited statement – delayed by the government shutdown in October – the Department of Commerce said the pace of the US recovery had picked up. The health of the economy has been closely scrutinised by investors eager to gauge how soon the Fed will decide to "taper" the $85bn (£52bn) a month bond-buying programme it has been using to try to kickstart growth. Bernanke, the Fed chairman, sparked a bout of chaos in world markets that became known as the "taper tantrum" earlier this year, after he suggested starting to withdraw the Fed's unprecedented programme of economic stimulus over the coming months. Experts have warned that this early estimate of GDP may be more tentative than usual, because the government shutdown may have hampered efforts to collect data. The BEA said that the acceleration in growth was broadly based, with consumer spending, stockbuilding by firms, state and local government spending, and property investment, all making a positive contribution. Thursday's data, which cover the third quarter of the year, do not yet reflect any damage inflicted on the US economy by the 16 day government shutdown that saw hundreds of thousands of public sector workers down tools in October as politicians on Capitol Hill wrangled over budget cuts. Another crucial indicator of the state of the US economy will come on Friday, with the delayed monthly jobs report. Bernanke has made unemployment the key indicator of when the Fed will choose to act, promising to leave interest rates on hold at least until the unemployment rate falls to 6.5% — provided inflation remains under control. The Fed's Open Market Committee will hold two more meetings before Bernanke bows out at the end of January, when he is expected to be replaced by Janet Yellen, if she can win over sceptical Senators at forthcoming confirmation hearings.

webTitle: UK gas market not rigged in 2012, regulators conclude

fields.standfirst: Financial Conduct Authority and Ofgem say there is no evidence of market manipulation last year
fields.body:
The embattled energy industry was given a lift on Thursday when a 12-month investigation by regulators into alleged rigging of the wholesale gas market ended with a clean bill of health.

The dual inquiry by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and Ofgem concentrated on six suspicious trades at the end of the gas market trading year in 2012. It concluded there was no evidence of market manipulation.

The energy and climate change secretary, Ed Davey, said the watchdogs had been given credible explanations by the sellers for the relevant, below-market-price trades and failed to find evidence that disputed them.

"Ofgem and the FCA have conducted a rigorous review and have not found evidence of market manipulation in this case. Market abuse is a very serious concern and I'm determined that where it exists, the full force of the law is brought to bear," he said.

"That's why we're introducing annual competition reviews to make sure the energy market is operating properly, and we're proposing to introduce criminal sanctions for manipulation of the energy markets."

The Department of Energy & Climate Change only formally gave powers to Ofgem to investigate manipulation in the energy market in June of this year. Those powers gave the regulator licence to impose civil sanctions but the aim is to extend this so that rigging of the gas market could have the same penalties as manipulating the financial markets. This could include a potential seven-year jail sentence.

Seth Freedman, the price reporter who first raised the gas market allegations with the regulators last November, said he was unable to comment on the case after signing an agreement with his former employer Isis-Heren.

But in a piece written on 14 March before the gagging order was in place he expressed concerns about the way the investigation was being handled. He said: "Despite being presented with a substantial cache of evidence, Ofgem officials stated they had neither the required powers nor comprehension to properly investigate the suspicious trading, and didn't bother interviewing key witnesses as part of their probe."

webTitle: Vodafone fails to hit legal minimum for 3G mobile internet coverage

fields.bodyText: Vodafone has been singled out by the telecoms watchdog for providing the poorest geographical coverage for 3G mobile internet in the UK after breaching the terms of its spectrum licence. Ofcom tests published on Thursday show that despite being the only British-owned operator in the country, Vodafone is also alone in having missed the legal obligation to extend 3G mobile coverage to 90% of the population by June this year. Ofcom plans to meet with all four networks in the coming weeks in response to growing consumer unrest about signal blackspots. Evidence gathered by the Guardian from over 1,000 readers shows many are reporting a deterioration since networks began rolling out 4G services. Vodafone is one of the largest mobile network operators in the world, but its investment in mobile internet in its home market has been behind rivals O2, which is owned by a Spanish company, the French and German joint venture EE, and the UK's smallest operator Three, which is part of a Hong Kong conglomerate. In 2010, in exchange for increasing the lease of 3G licences from 25 years to an indefinite duration, and releasing 4G spectrum to help speed up mobile broadband, the government increased the minimum coverage obligation for 3G from 80% to 90%. The deadline was 30 June, but Ofcom tests carried out that month showed Vodafone missed the target by 1.4%. It was the only network to fall short. The company has promised to boost its signal, but the work will not be complete until January 2014. If Vodafone misses the new deadline, Ofcom has the power to impose a fine of up to 10% of relevant turnover. Ofcom said: "Vodafone has put in place a plan to bring itself into compliance with the 3G coverage obligation by the end of 2013. This will involve rolling out 3G to more mobile masts than Vodafone had originally estimated as being necessary. Ofcom has reviewed this plan, and believes it to be credible, but will closely monitor Vodafone's implementation of the plan." Vodafone will upgrade about 100 existing 2G sites to make them 3G sites in the run-up to Christmas – the sites were originally planned for upgrade in the first quarter of 2014. webTitle: Twitter IPO: shares expected to rise sharply on US stock market debut

fields.standfirst: Shares in social media company could soar by as much as 70%, according to spread-betting firm IG
fields.body:
Twitter shares are expected to rise sharply when they debut on the US stock market on Thursday and could soar by as much as 70%, according to one spread-betting firm.

The social media company will sell 70m shares priced at $26 each, valuing the company at more than $14bn when it lists on the New York Stock Exchange.

The spread-betting firm IG is predicting the share price will spike initially, as investors rush to be part of the latest technology flotation.

IG's grey market, which allows clients to take a view on how much Twitter will be worth after the first official day of trading, implies the shares will rise to $43.60 on debut day, valuing the company at $23.7bn.

David Jones, chief market strategist at IG, said: "At the moment, based on all the hype around it and our grey market, we are expecting a sharp rise when trading starts. Whether or not they hang on to the gains is to be seen. There are question marks over how money will be made in the years ahead."

Twitter, based in San Francisco, will be hoping to avoid a repeat of Facebook's disastrous flotation last year. Facebook initially sold shares at the top end of its range but suffered technical glitches and the shares crashed shortly after the IPO.

Twitter had already revised up its target price range to $23-$25 from $17-$20, before further increasing the price to $26 a share on Wednesday night after strong demand from investors.

Twitter will have a total of 545m shares in issue, rising to about 695m when restricted stock and options are included, which takes valuation of the company at the initial price of $26 to $18bn.

Twitter's IPO will make billions for some of Silicon Valley's top names, including the co-founders Ev Williams, who owns 59.6m shares and will add $1.47bn-plus to his net worth from the sale, and Jack Dorsey, who owns 23.4m shares.

Twitter's other backers include Amazon's founder Jeff Bezos and Marc Andreessen, Netscape's founder turned serial investor.

It will be the second largest US internet IPO on record, behind Facebook, and the third largest US IPO this year.
